channel.title: cata-list
channel.description: Useful lists of some of the best info, media, tools, and quotes for those who seek to understand and improve this world.

item.title: After Pork Giant Was Exposed for Cruel Killings, the FBI Pursued Its Critics
item.description: The agency, seeking information on an animal rights group, attempted to recruit a former truck driver as an informant, the truck driver says.

item.title: China Targets Rare Earth Export Curbs to Hobble US Defense Industry
item.description: Beijing asks industry executives if proposed restrictions will harm western contractors.

item.title: 'New Car Smell' Is the Scent of Carcinogens, and Even Short Trips May Overexpose Us
item.description: The average American spends almost one hour each day commuting to work, a number that adds up quickly.

item.title: What the New York Times' Hit Piece on Slate Star Codex Says About Media Gatekeeping
item.description: 'Silicon Valley's Safe Space' has misinformed readers.

item.title: Fake Amazon Reviews 'Being Sold in Bulk' Online
item.description: A Which? investigation found 10 sites offering fake Amazon Marketplace reviews from as little as £5 each.

item.title: With a Star Science Reporter's Purging, Mob Culture at the New York Times Enters a Strange New Phase
item.description: Speaking recently at a Quillette Free Thought Lives event, Columbia University professor John McWhorter expounded on his thesis that social justice comprises an ersatz religion, complete with rites…

item.title: The Untold History of America's Zero-Day Market
item.description: The lucrative business of dealing in code vulnerabilities is central to espionage and war planning, which is why brokers never spoke about it—until now.

item.title: White House Cites 'Deep Concerns' About WHO COVID Report, Demands Early Data From China
item.description: The White House on Saturday called on China to make available data from the earliest days of the COVID-19 outbreak, saying it has 'deep concerns' about the way the findings of the World Health Organization's COVID-19 report were communicated.

item.title: How Billions in Pandemic Aid Was Swindled by Con Artists and Crime Syndicates
item.description: A senior federal law enforcement source said the fraud is so complex and multilayered that it will take months to develop a full accounting.

item.title: Hackers, Mason Jars, and the Psychedelic Science of DIY Shrooms
item.description: The history of home cultivation methods of Psilocybe is more connected to early internet culture than you'd think.

item.title: LA Cops Tried Using Instagram's Copyright Filter to Stop Someone From Filming Them
item.description: Over the last several weeks, police in Beverly Hills have been caught on video seemingly trying to weaponize Instagram's copyright detection algorithms to get a prominent LA activist banned from the platform.

item.title: Making the Profane Sacred
item.description: 'By making a statute and by defining blasphemy, the church sought to prevent discussion—sought to prevent argument—sought to prevent a man giving his honest opinion. Certainly a tenet, a dogma, a d…

item.title: The Long Hack: How China Exploited a U.S. Tech Supplier
item.description: For years, U.S. investigators found tampering in products made by Super Micro Computer Inc. The company says it was never told. Neither was the public.

item.title: China Refuses to Give WHO Raw Data on Early Covid-19 Cases
item.description: WHO investigators said Chinese authorities wouldn't give them personalized data that could help them determine how and when the coronavirus first began to spread in China.

item.title: Unspeakable Truths About Racial Inequality in America
item.description: This is the text of a lecture delivered by the author as part of the Benson Center Lecture Series at the University of Colorado, Boulder, on February 8th, 2021. I am a black American intellectual l…

item.title: MIT Researchers Created a System That Prints Functional Drones and Robots
item.description: LaserFactory cuts out a shape, then adds circuitry and components.

item.title: Mediocrity Is Now Mandatory
item.description: From stimulus to school admissions, leaders act as if ease is the only worthy goal.

item.title: Beating Back Cancel Culture: A Case Study From the Field of Artificial Intelligence
item.description: It's easy to decry cancel culture, but hard to turn it back. Thankfully, recent developments in my area of academic specialty—artificial intelligence (AI)—show that fighting cancel culture isn't im…

item.title: The Journalistic Tattletale and Censorship Industry Suffers Several Well-Deserved Blows
item.description: The NYT's Taylor Lorenz falsely accuses a tech investor of using a slur after spending months trying to infiltrate and monitor a new app that allows free conversation.

item.title: Uighurs: 'Credible Case' China Carrying Out Genocide
item.description: A legal opinion concludes the Chinese government has shown an intent to destroy the Uighur minority.

item.title: Wuhan Residents Remember Coronavirus 'Whistleblower' Doctor a Year After His Death
item.description: A year after his death from COVID-19, residents in the Chinese city of Wuhan say they remain grateful to the 'whistleblower' doctor who first sounded the alarm about the outbreak before it received official recognition.

item.title: SpaceX Plans Starlink Phone Service, Emergency Backup, and Low-Income Access
item.description: SpaceX's latest petition to the FCC details some of its Starlink plans.

item.title: Leading Baby Food Manufacturers Knowingly Sold Products With High Levels of Toxic Metals, a Congressional Investigation Found
item.description: Internal documents from major baby food manufacturers show they tested and used ingredients with high levels of arsenic, lead, cadmium and mercury in the baby food they sold to parents, according to a congressional investigation.

item.title: 'More Weight': An Academic's Guide to Surviving Campus Witch Hunts
item.description: In the fall of 2020, I became the target of a cancellation campaign after I'd suggested that the best policy for a university seeking to support underrepresented groups, while staying true to its m…

item.title: American Cities Are Way Underreporting Their Carbon Footprints
item.description: A modeling system called Vulcan shows that on average, cities across the country pollute 18.3 percent more than they've estimated.

item.title: Mysterious California Sea Lion Deaths Linked to Toxic Synthetic Chemicals
item.description: Scientists say animals with higher levels of DDT, PCBs and others in their blubber are more prone to cancer triggered by herpes

item.title: Electric Cars Would Save America Huge Amounts of Energy
item.description: Electrifying the vehicle fleet would save more energy than we get from the entire power grid today.

item.title: Did the BLM Protests Against the Police Lead to the 2020 Spike in Homicides?
item.description: Serious crime, particularly murder, soared while everyone was supposed to be locked indoors. Between 2019—by no means a famously peaceful year—and 2020, homicides alone surged by 42 percent during …

item.title: Apple CEO Sounds Warning of Algorithms Pushing Society Towards Catastrophe
item.description: Tim Cook says there will be consequences to having 'rampant disinformation and conspiracy theories juiced by algorithms'.

item.title: U.S. Intelligence Claims China Wants to Steal Your DNA
item.description: China has been accused of stealing a lot of things from America: intellectual property, 'jobs and wealth,' even our role as the world's biggest jerk. Now, US national security officials warn that America's greatest adversary wants to steal our genetic makeup.

item.title: Suck It, Wall Street
item.description: In a blowout comedy for the ages, finance pirates take it up the clacker

item.title: Social Media Damages Teenagers' Mental Health, Report Says
item.description: Heavy social media use had a negative impact on wellbeing, the study found.

item.title: Meet the Censored: Live Streamers
item.description: Silicon Valley is shutting down speech loopholes. The latest target: live content

item.description: Silicon Valley is shutting down speech loopholes. The latest target: live content

item.title: Worrisome New Coronavirus Mutations Are Emerging. Why Now?
item.description: Across the globe, SARS-CoV-2 is evolving ways to evade the immune system and become more infectious. Blown pandemic response plans are to blame.

item.title: Air Pollution Linked to Higher Risk of Irreversible Sight Loss
item.description: Large UK study found small pollution rise associated with more cases of age-related macular degeneration

item.title: Reflecting the Authoritarian Climate, Washington Will Remain Militarized Until at Least March
item.description: The idea of troops in U.S. streets for an extended period of time -- an extreme measure even when temporary -- has now become close to a sacred consensus.

item.title: Earth Has Lost 28 Trillion Tons of Ice Since the Mid-1990s
item.description: Melt has accelerated over recent decades, contributing to sea level rise

item.title: No Qualified Immunity for Cops Who Made Stuff Up to Justify Seizing a Man's Phone for Twelve Days
item.description: Here's an interesting decision [PDF] by the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals. On one hand, it says cops can possibly hassle people for filming them if they can find almost any reason at all to justify it. On the other hand, it says they definitely...

item.title: The War on Privacy
item.description: Five years ago, official abuses of secrecy were the scandal. Today, the scandal is you

item.title: SpaceX Sets New Record for Most Satellites on a Single Launch With Latest Falcon 9 Mission
item.description: SpaceX has set a new all-time record for the most satellites launched and deployed on a single mission, with its Transporter-1 flight on Sunday. The launch was the first of SpaceX's dedicated rideshare missions, in which it splits up the payload capacity of its rocket among multiple customers…

item.title: Glenn Greenwald: 'Journalists Are Authoritarians'
item.description: What went wrong at the outlet he co-founded, what's wrong with the ACLU, and what might go wrong in the Biden administration

item.title: Electric Vehicles Close to 'Tipping Point' of Mass Adoption
item.description: Sales increase 43% globally in 2020 as plunging battery costs mean the cars will soon be the cheapest vehicles to buy

item.title: Intelligence Analysts Use U.S. Smartphone Location Data Without Warrants, Memo Says
item.description: The disclosure comes amid growing legislative scrutiny of how the government uses commercially available location records.

item.title: The Moronic Firing of Will Wilkinson Illustrates Why Fear and Bad Faith Mob Demands Reign Supreme
item.description: In the prevailing climate, the rational choice is to avoid social scorn and ostracization no matter how baseless the grievances one must appease.

item.title: The Echo Chamber Era
item.description: Trust in media is down, but if journalists don't listen to critics anyway, why should they care?

item.title: Forever Chemicals Are Widespread in U.S. Drinking Water
item.description: Experts hope that with the incoming Biden administration, the federal government will finally regulate a class of chemicals known as PFASs

item.title: Vertical Farms Grow Veggies on Site at Restaurants and Grocery Stores
item.description: Last month we reported that a huge vertical farming operation near Copenhagen in Denmark recently completed its first harvest. That setup uses hydroponics, but the veggies grown in Vertical Field urban farming pods take root in real soil.

item.title: Palantir's God's-Eye View of Afghanistan
item.description: The company's software can sift through enormous amounts of data, and those metrics can be used to make life-or-death decisions.

item.title: Social Media Bans Are Really, Actually, Shockingly Common
item.description: Booting Trump didn't set a precedent. From Yelp to Uber to Airbnb, platforms regularly ban users and content, but too often behind the scenes.

item.title: Could Lab-Grown Plant Tissue Ease the Environmental Toll of Logging and Agriculture?
item.description: MIT researchers have proposed a method for growing plant-based materials, like wood and fiber, in a lab. The technology is still in early development but might one day help reduce the environmental footprint of some types of agriculture.

item.title: The Ongoing Collapse of the World's Aquifers
item.description: When humans over-exploit underground water supplies, the ground collapses like a huge empty water bottle. It's called subsidence, and it could affect 1.6 billion people by 2040.

item.title: The SolarWinds Hackers Used Tactics Other Groups Will Copy
item.description: The supply chain threat was just the beginning.

item.title: A New SolarWinds Malware Strain Is Discovered
item.description: SolarWinds: it's the hack that keeps on growing. On Monday, researchers announced the discovery of yet another malware strain used by foreign hackers to infiltrate a wide milieu of American government agencies and companies.

item.title: The New Domestic War on Terror Is Coming
item.description: No speculation is needed. Those who wield power are demanding it. The only question is how much opposition they will encounter.

item.title: Behind a Secret Deal Between Google and Facebook
item.description: Facebook was going to compete with Google for some advertising sales but backed away from the plan after the companies cut a preferential deal, according to court documents.

item.title: 2020 Was the One of the Hottest Years on Record
item.description: Officials from NASA and NOAA say the warming of both the planet's air and water are driving weather disasters.

item.title: Left Stranded: US Military Sonar Linked to Whale Beachings in Pacific, Say Scientists
item.description: Islands surrounded by US military study area, including Guam and Saipan, call for activity that harms the whales to stop

item.title: Beyond Platforms: Private Censorship, Parler, and the Stack
item.description: Last week, following riots that saw supporters of President Trump breach and sack parts of the Capitol building, Facebook and Twitter made the decision to give the president the boot. That was notable enough, given that both companies had previously treated the president, like other political...

item.title: Billionaires Add $1tn to Net Worth During Pandemic as Their Workers Struggle
item.description: Companies' attempts at hazard pay have been paltry and fleeting as employees are threatened for protesting working conditions

item.title: Everything We Know Now About Schools, Kids, and Covid-19
item.description: Researchers are finally getting good data on how severely SARS-CoV-2 affects children and how they transmit it. What does it mean for reopening classrooms?

item.title: The Antifa Thugs Shame America
item.description: Andy Ngo's family came to the US to escape Communist tyranny — now he's fleeing a political mob

item.title: Cult Nation
item.description: National politics has robbed us of our selves.

item.description: New research has dug into the openings that iOS and Android security provide for anyone with the right tools.

item.title: Tech Companies Are Profiling Us From Before Birth
item.description: Children today are the very first generation of citizens to be datafied from before birth. The social and political consequences of this historical transformation have yet to be seen.

item.title: Trump's Twitter Ban Obscures the Real Problem: State-Backed Manipulation Is Rampant on Social Media
item.description: Social media censorship in the US fails to tackle the rising trend of 'disinformation-for-hire' cyber troops.

item.title: Nasa's Curiosity Rover: 3,000 Days on Mars
item.description: Three thousand days and counting: Nasa's Curiosity rover continues its extraordinary exploration of Mars.

item.title: The Arctic Ocean Is Teeming With Microfibers From Clothes
item.description: Scientists find an average of 40 microplastic particles per cubic meter of the northern water. The likely source? The synthetic clothing in our washing machines.

item.title: How Silicon Valley, in a Show of Monopolistic Force, Destroyed Parler
item.description: In the last three months, tech giants have censored political speech and journalism to manipulate U.S. politics, while liberals, with virtual unanimity, have cheered.

item.title: The Mafia Is Thriving in Lockdown
item.description: Chaos has always been an opportunity for organised crime — as Britain could soon find out

item.title: The Plan to Build a Global Network of Floating Power Stations
item.description: A lot of thermal energy is trapped in the ocean. An ex-NASA researcher has figured out how it might generate unlimited clean power for aquatic robots.

item.title: SolarWinds Hackers Shared Tricks With Known Russian Cyberspies
item.description: Security researchers have found links between the attackers and Turla, a sophisticated team suspected of operating out of Moscow's FSB intelligence agency.

item.title: We Need a New Media System
item.description: If you sell culture war all day, don't be surprised by the real-world consequences

item.title: What Would It Take to Run a City on 100 Percent Clean Energy?
item.description: Most claims of running on 'clean' electricity come with caveats, and many technologies required for round-the-clock renewable energy aren't quite ready yet.

item.title: Violence in the Capitol, Dangers in the Aftermath
item.description: From the Cold War to the War on Terror: the harms from authoritarian 'solutions' are often greater than the threats they are ostensibly designed to combat.

item.description: On the case of Julian Assange, and fearing empire more than Trump

item.title: EFF's Response to Social Media Companies' Decisions to Block President Trump's Accounts
item.description: Like most people in the United States and around the world, EFF is shocked and disgusted by Wednesday's violent attack on the U.S. Capitol. We support all those who are working to defend the Constitution and the rule of law, and we are grateful for the service of policymakers, staffers, and other...

item.title: Climate Change Is Turning Cities Into Ovens
item.description: A new model estimates that by 2100, cities across the world could warm as much as 4.4 degrees Celsius. It's a deadly consequence of the heat-island effect.

item.title: Sealed U.S. Court Records Exposed in SolarWinds Breach
item.description: The ongoing breach affecting thousands of organizations that relied on backdoored products by network software firm SolarWinds may have jeopardized the privacy of countless sealed court documents on file with the U.S. federal court system, according to a memo released Wednesday by the Administrative…

item.title: SolarWinds Hackers Accessed More Than 3,000 DOJ Email Accounts
item.description: In yet another dastardly twist in the ongoing SolarWinds debacle, the U.S. Department of Justice announced Wednesday that hackers had accessed the inboxes of over 3,000 DOJ employee Microsoft email accounts.

item.description: The FBI, NSA and CISA say it'll take a lot of effort to fix the problem.

item.description: Gravitricity and Energy Vault are pioneering a radical new alternative to batteries for grid storage

item.title: Researchers Find a Faster, More Efficient Way to 3D Print
item.description: Two researchers at Penn State have created a new system for five-axis additive 3D-printing that reduces the amount and density of support materials needed for making printed objects.

item.description: Officials say visas not yet approved for World Health Organization delegation due to visit Wuhan

item.description: The startup TuSimple is deploying tractor-trailers that drive themselves from pickup to delivery

item.description: For decades, scientists have been hot-wiring viruses in hopes of preventing a pandemic, not causing one. But what if …?

item.description: The NYU Professor becomes the latest academic to fall afoul of idea police

item.description: The real measure of how free is a society is not how its mainstream, well-behaved ruling class servants are treated, but the fate of its actual dissidents.

item.description: Today's SJWs believe all that needs to be done to bring about a new world is to destroy the old one

item.description: U.S. President Donald Trump's pardon of four American men convicted of killing Iraqi civilians while working as contractors in 2007 violated U.S. obligations under international law, U.N. human rights experts said on Wednesday.

item.title: The New Coronavirus Variant Is in the U.S.—Now What?
item.description: Over the past 24 hours, health officials in Colorado have reported finding two suspected cases of covid-19 caused by a worrying new variant of the coronavirus.

item.description: About 1,115 prisoners of the the total 1,236 prisoners at the Goose Creek correctional center had tested positive

item.title: How Your Digital Trails Wind Up in the Police's Hands
item.description: Phone calls. Web searches. Location tracks. Smart speaker requests. They've become crucial tools for law enforcement, while users often are unaware.
